Chapter  Twenty-Six 


The  tour  took  surprisingly  long.  Despite  each  of  the  two 
sections  being  only  about  five  metres  wide,  there  was  quite  a 
lot  of  area  to  cover  along  the  rim  of  the  disk. 

I didn‚Äôt  pay  too  much  attention  to  the  specifics  of  the 
layout,  still  preoccupied  by  the  social  questions.  From  the  little 
I gathered,  Alpha-2,  where  we  had  come  down,  was  mostly 
cabins  and  restrooms.  There  was  a specific  room  for  men‚Äôs 
showers  and  another  for  women‚Äôs  showers.  None  of  the  cabins 
had  dedicated  toilets,  and  visitors  had  to  use  communal  toilets 
located  in  restrooms  that  jutted  out  from  the  external  wall  in 
the  hall  (creating  the  bend  in  the  wall  that  I had  noticed 
earlier). 

There  were  two  elevators  per  section,  one  on  each  side  of 
the  disk.  At  any  given  time  one  of  the  elevators  would  be  up  at 
the  core  while  the  other  would  be  waiting  on  the  rim,  so  there 
was  an  occasional  wait  to  go  up,  but  rarely  one  for  going  down. 
Each  elevator  opened  into  a waiting  room  like  that  where  we 
met  the  scientists,  and  there  was  an  additional  viewing  room 
half-way  between  the  elevators  on  one  side  of  the  disk  where 


people  could  watch  screens  showing  views  from  outside  the 
station. 

Alpha-2  was  connected  to  Alpha-1  by  four  doorways  that 
resembled  the  airlock  we  had  bypassed  to  enter  the  station. 
Other  doorways  could  be  seen  on  the  outer  walls  of  the  disk 
that  were  sealed  permanently  shut. 

‚ÄúThe  sections  are  modular.  When  Olympus  first  came 
online  it  only  had  two  sections.  Now  it  has  five.  I hope  to 
continue  expanding  and  improving  the  station  until  there‚Äôs 
enough  space  here  for  a whole  city,‚Äù  explained  Stephano 
proudly  to  all  that  were  present.  ‚ÄúOne  consequence  of  the 
modularity  is  that  these  doors,  given  that  there‚Äôs  no  section  on 
the  other  side  to  walk  to,  open  into  vacuum.  There  are 
spacesuits  located  in  the  wall-panels  here,  but  in  case  of 
emergency  you  are  under  no  circumstances  to  try  and  force 
one  of  these  airlocks  open.  You‚Äôll  vent  the  entire  disk,  possibly 
killing  everyone  inside,  and  unless  you‚Äôre  a trained  astronaut 
you‚Äôll  probably  end  up  killing  yourself  as  well.  The  doors  are 
locked  mechanically,  magnetically,  and  electronically,  so 
there‚Äôs  very  little  danger,  but  people  get  dumb  during  crisis 
and  I don‚Äôt  want  any  mishaps.  If  something  should  happen  I 
urge  you  to  return  to  your  cabins  and  wait  for  our  professionals 
to  fix  things.  You‚Äôll  just  be  getting  in  the  way  otherwise.‚Äù 

Alpha-1  had  a few  more  cabins.  I saw  Kokumo  trying  her 
best  to  adjust  to  being  in  space  and  Malka  reading  something 
or  another  on  a wallscreen.  The  other  soldiers  and  the  other 
Aguila  we  hadn‚Äôt  met  (Michel  Watanabe)  were  in  a section  of

Zephyr  was  nowhere  to  be  found. 

We  took  a tour  of  the  kitchen  last.  In  it  was  the  most

course,  with  the  com  system  disabled,  Las  Aguilas  would  have

The  wireless  network  was  supposed  to  be  down,  but  there 
were  times  during  the  tour  that  I thought  I could  sense 
something  on  our  antenna.  Perhaps  it  was  some  local  com 
pinging  to  see  if  there  was  a network  or  something.

More  optimal  to  use  the  opportunity  to  our  advantage. 

‚ÄúUgh!  It‚Äôs  bizarre.  There‚Äôs  some  kind  of  software  corruption

Stephano  led  the  way  to  the  storage  room  between  Alpha

As  it  came  online  again  Stephano‚Äôs  com  lit  up  with

‚ÄúThe  human  should  signal  that  it  is  receiving  my  signal.  A

Stephano  tapped  his  com  furiously  and  said 
‚ÄúAcknowledged!  We  have  been  dealing  with  minor  computer

‚ÄúThe  human  should  know  that  protocol  has  been  agreed

The  nameless  were  here. 


Chapter  Twenty-Seven 


‚ÄúRemember  your  primary  mission:  Defuse  tension  between

(And  the  third  goal:  Find  out  whether  the  crystal  we  run  on

The  voice  of  Stephano  came  over  the  com  that  had  been

Gamma-section  was  how  we  left  it:  dark,  heavy,  and  empty. 
It  was  trivially  easy  to  see  the  nameless,  who  were  standing 
only  ten  metres  from  the  elevator  door. 

The  pair  had  taken  off  the  environment  suit  that  they  had 
to  use  when  moving  from  their  ship  to  the  disk.  Vista  noted  it 
lying  in  a heap  on  the  floor.  The  nameless  paid  it  no  mind. 
Instead,  the  creature  seemed  to  be  engaged  in...  juggling. 

The  nameless  did  not  have  bodies  like  animals  on  Earth. 
Nearly  all  Terran  animals  were  bilaterally  symmetric,  or  at  least 
radially  symmetric  (like  worms).  Both  nameless  species  had 
four-fold  symmetry.  The  nameless  animal  on  top  had  four  eyes 
and  four  ‚Äúarms‚Äù  each  with  four  thick,  boneless  ‚Äúfingers‚Äù.  The 
animal  on  the  bottom,  carrying  the  top  animal,  had  four  trunk-

eyes.  The  eyes  were  distributed  between  their  limbs,  resulting 
in  one  eye  above  each  leg  and  under  each  arm.  They  had  no 
front  and  no  back,  merely  four  identical  sides. 

The  nameless‚Äô  arms  were  moving  in  unison,  throwing  four 
small  white  or  purple  (impossible  to  tell  in  this  lighting)  balls 
between  its  hands.  It  wasn‚Äôt  amazing  in  the  way  that  humans 
could  sometimes  use  two  hands  to  juggle  six  or  more  objects, 
but  it  was  mildly  impressive  considering  the  gravity  and 
Coriolis  effects  (from  the  rotation). 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs  juggling,‚Äù  said  Body. 


‚ÄúExcellent.  You  lucked  out  that  they  sent  Jester.  At  least,  it‚Äôs

Body  kept  its  distance  and  waved.  I instructed  Body  to

The  aliens  did  something  of  a dance,  spinning  around  in  a

That  impressed  me.  Nameless  were  bigger  than  humans,  and

‚Äúshoulder‚Äù  of  the  arms  at  about  190cm  tall.  Dancing  under  the

Despite  the  little  spin,  the  nameless  didn‚Äôt  respond.  Was  its

‚ÄúYou  are  a robot.  You  look  like  a human,‚Äù  came  a flat

‚ÄúYes.  I am  a machine  that  thinks.  I am  here  to  talk  with

‚ÄúMany  people  know  of  this  miracle.  This  is  why  the

This  was  strange.  If  the  nameless  despised  physical

‚ÄúThis  is  true.  I remember  the  human-way.  You  look  like  a

‚ÄúTHIS  IS  WRONG.  All  people  know  that  Earth  is

(No!  Body  will  stay  silent!)  rebuked  Safety  in  response  to

Jester  was  quiet  for  a while,  bobbing  occasionally  but  never

‚ÄúYou  are  a machine,‚Äù  said  Jester,  breaking  the  silence  only

‚Äú ‚ÄòAnd  what  of  emotion?  Surely  there  is  something  non-

As  Body  rode  the  elevator  down  to  Alpha-section  I

The  door  closed  behind  Body  and  soft  music  came  on

¬´As  evidenced  by  how  you  work  with  terrorists  and-¬ª 
Slovinsky  cut  his  com  off  and  began  blocking  attempts  to  reach

Body  had  reached  the  portion  of  the  elevator  shaft  where

Dream  disagreed.  (Your  thinking  has  two  major  flaws.  The

(There‚Äôs  definitely  something  big  that  we‚Äôre  missing,}

Dream  ignored  his  brother.  (Secondly,  why  would  the

(Gallo  was  in  charge,  though.  We  all  saw  her  act  with

I thought  about  Mobius  Connectomics.  Slovinsky  wrote  in

‚Äúfailing  parts‚Äù  in  the  human  body  with  mechanical  analogues

Given  several  dedicated  hours  of  thought  I probably

Body  pried  open  the  door,  feeling  the  air  blast  out  of  the

Body  was  stronger  than  the  motor,  but  only  by  a little  bit. 


Safety  manoeuvred  Body  through  the  door  and  let  it  snap

Heart  had  been  in  constant  contact  with  Zephyr.  All  of  Las

It  was  time  we  didn‚Äôt  have.  The  cyborg  was  loose  in  the

I did  my  best  to  explain  what  we  knew  to  Zephyr  as  Body

Safety  stopped  Body  at  the  access  panels  to  the  elevators

We  paused  a moment  to  develop  a strategy  for  what  to  do

As  Body  floated  down  the  tube,  I focused  on  the

‚ÄúPlease  be  careful,  Crystal.‚Äù  Zephyr‚Äôs  voice  had  the  cold

‚ÄúI‚Äôm  actually  incapable  of  being  reckless.  My  programming

Zephyr‚Äôs  only  response  was  a sigh. 

Body  reached  the  airlock  that  led  to  the  alien  ship  and

was  jammed  open.  Normally  the  internal  door  would  be

Body  tapped  the  screen,  signalling  that  it  was  okay  to

The  air  pressure  in  the  nameless  environment  was  higher  than 
on  Earth,  and  the  resulting  wind  that  blew  out  through  the 
corridor  was  fierce.  We  could  immediately  see  why  the

The  initial  rush  of  air  subsided  to  merely  that  which  was

There  was  very  little  light  in  the  nameless  airlock,  but  we

The  airlock  in  the  nameless  ship  was  very  dark,  darker

nameless  homeworld  was  thought  to  be  a very  dark  place,  but

The  room  was  about  four  or  five  metres  in  diameter,

The  only  real  feature  in  the  room  was  the  wall  opposite  the

Body  kicked  off  the  airlock  door.  Vista  was  fascinated.  We

impossibly  complex  flow,  grabbing  hold  of  each  other  and 
sliding  past  without  any  apparent  lubrication.  It  seemed  alive. 

There  were  no  hand-holds  to  brace  against.  No  gravity  to 
stop  our  approach.  No  other  features  in  the  room.  Slovinsky 
must  have  gone  somewhere,  and  all  signs  pointed  to  the 
surface  of  the  far  wall.  Safety  began  to  scream  in  protest  as  he 
realized  that  Body  was  going  to  collide  with  the  shimmering

Body‚Äôs  legs  touched  first,  and  the  wall  of  machines  reacted

the  wall,  glowing  white  around  the  edges  of  where  the  limbs 
were  now  dipping  into  the  fluid.  Body  tried  kicking.  Its  legs 
moved  freely,  unimpeded,  but  were  still  drawn  in,  as  though 
they  were  being  devoured.  Body‚Äôs  torso  and  arms  were  soon 
enveloped  by  the  machines.  The  silver  substance  hardly  felt 
like  anything  when  it  touched  Body‚Äôs  hands.  Surprisingly 
smooth.  The  temperature  was  increasing.  The  pulling  was  ever 
stronger. 

And  then  we  were  through  the  barrier. 


Chapter  Thirty 


Body  slammed  down  hard  on  the  floor  of  the  alien  ship. 

{Gravity?!} 

Indeed,  we  were  in  some  gravitational  well.  Our 
accelerometers  reported  that  we  were  now  in  an  environment 
that  replicated  the  conditions  of  the  nameless‚Äô  homeworld,  at 
least  according  to  most  scholars.  2.87  times  Earth  gravity.  33.1 
degrees  Celsius.  The  air  was  incredibly  heavy  and  wet.  Wiki 
had  explained  that,  in  addition  to  having  a thicker  atmosphere 
because  of  the  increased  gravity,  the  nameless  air  had  a high 
concentration  of  C02,  making  it  abnormally  dense. 

The  only  way  a planet  with  such  a strong  greenhouse  effect 
could  be  this  temperature  was  if  it  was  quite  distant  from  its 
home  star,  and  the  nameless  ship‚Äôs  ambient  light  level  reflected 
that.  There  was  a faint  purple  glow  above  Body,  and  there 
were  glowing  signs  on  the  walls,  but  it  was  generally  very  dark, 
even  if  not  as  dark  as  the  airlock. 

The  ground  under  Body  was  soft.  Dirt.  It  seemed  magical 
to  touch  dirt  while  in  space. 


{How  is  there  this  much  gravity?  What‚Äôs  causing  the 
acceleration?)  pondered  Wiki. 

(If  the  nameless  have  found  some  source  of  artificial

rotation,  or  a cylindrical  shape,}  speculated  Vista. 

(You‚Äôre  proposing  something  which  violates  the  known 
laws  of  physics!  It‚Äôs  safer  to  assume  we‚Äôre  just  confused!} 
rebuked  Wiki,  unwilling  to  accept  the  explanation. 

(If  the  nameless  have  artificial  gravity,  it  implies  not  just  a

lack.  They  are  far  more  of  a threat  than  we  expected,  given  this

{First  things  first,}  reminded  Heart.  {We  need  to  track

Safety  had  pulled  Body  off  the  black  dirt  and  brushed  it  off. 
Behind  it  was  the  shimmering  curtain  of  machines,  while  to

either  cared  very  much  about  their  aesthetic  or  there  was 
something  significant  that  we  were  overlooking. 

{What  if  it‚Äôs  a portal?}  imagined  Dream. 

Body  walked  forward  through  the  corridor  of  stone.  Above

ceiling  was  higher  than  that,  but  we  couldn‚Äôt  tell  exactly  how

a featureless  sky,  for  all  we  knew. 

{What  insanity  are  you  espousing  now?}  asked  Wiki,  rising

(What  if  the  silver  wall  teleported  us  to  the  nameless‚Äô

(You‚Äôre  trying  to  explain  unexpected  gravity  by  postulating

{You  just  wait  and  see,}  thought  Dream. 

The  stone  walls  had  markings  on  them  in  luminescent

the  markings.  They  were  mostly  in  a faint  blue-white,  though 
there  was  occasional  orange-red.  They  were  splashed  here  and

child  had  decided  to  draw  on  the  walls  merely  for  the  fun  of  it. 

The  corridor  turned,  and  after  a few  metres  opened  up  into 
a broad  space.  Body‚Äôs  foot  sunk  into  mud.  The  ground  was

{A  swamp!  Fascinating,}  thought  Vista. 

{Technically  it‚Äôs  a fen  or  perhaps  just  a mire,}  corrected

{And  a mire  is  characterized  by  peat-forming  vegetation.

The  ‚Äúmudland‚Äù  was  expansive,  flat,  and  lifeless.  Here  and

A structure  caught  Vista‚Äôs  attention.  Body  wandered

(It‚Äôs  a staircase,}  decided  Vista.  (Going  up  into  the  ceiling.

(It‚Äôs  signalling  via  radio.  Feel  the  antenna?}  pointed  out

(There  are  other  signals  here,  too,}  realized  Safety.  (Too

The  only  warning  was  a high-pitched  hiss.  The  rocket  came

was  tough.  It‚Äôd  take  more  than  that  to  stop  us. 


Safety  took  executive  control,  pushing  Body  into  a run

I did  my  part.  ‚ÄúIvan!  Is  that  you?  We  surrender!  We‚Äôre  not

There  was,  however,  a point  to  talking  to  the  nameless. 
They  had  to  be  here,  somewhere.  I pushed  a message  through 
Body‚Äôs  antenna.  ‚ÄúI  am  here  only  to  deal  with  the  human!  I 
mean  none  of  you  any  harm!‚Äù  I broadcast  in  Xenolang. 

Another  rocket  flew  past.  It  shot  out  in  front  of  Body, 
missing  by  less  than  a metre.  The  smoke  from  its  wake  blinded 
us  momentarily,  but  Safety  pressed  on.  The  sound  of

‚ÄúTHE  HUMAN  EXPLAINED  YOUR  EVIL  BETRAYAL! 
WE  WILL  RAPE  YOUR  CORPSE  BEFORE  RAPING  ATT 
OF  YOUR  CHILDREN!‚Äù  came  the  response  on  the  radio,

ahead. 

Body  reached  the  relative  safety  of  what  we  could  now  see 
was  some  kind  of  vehicle,  turned  on  its  side  and  half-sunk  in

‚ÄúI  have  betrayed  no-one!  The  human  lied  to  you!‚Äù  I

There  was  a deep  rumbling  from  the  far  side  of  the  cover.

‚ÄúYOU  are  the  EVIL  COMMUNICATOR  that  is  wrong. 
THE  HUMAN  EXPLAINED!  The  island  is  united  around  this. 
Your  confusion  doesn‚Äôt  stop  our  violent  justice.  WE  WILL

‚ÄúWhat  violence  are  you  talking  about?!  I‚Äôve  done  nothing!‚Äù 
I sent  back. 

A rocket  impacted  the  side  of  the  wheeled  vehicle  we  were 
behind.  The  shockwave  and  a piece  of  shrapnel  slammed  into 
Body,  knocking  it  down.  Body  crawled  behind  the  truck  on

‚ÄúGood  god,  you  sound  so  much  like  Phoenix  right  now.

Dream  was  also  very  pro-Mars.  Like  an  artist  looking  at  a

If  we  had  managed  to  sway  Heart,  perhaps  even  into

There  was  a majority  in  favour  of  leaving  Earth  among  the

I,  naturally,  had  a more  selfish  reason  for  wanting  the

Not  only  would  The  Purpose  soar  at  finding  stronger

‚ÄúAlright.  We  won‚Äôt  force  anyone  along  who  doesn‚Äôt  want  to

Uncomfortable  thoughts  boiled  up  within  Avram.  With

‚ÄúYou  know  Anna  di  Malta,  right?  She‚Äôll  be  there.  If  you

‚ÄúCrystal...‚Äù  he  said,  annoyed  at  the  sound  of  annoyance  in

‚ÄúTime  to  go?‚Äù  asked  Zephyr,  clearly  mocking  his  silence. 

{Bitch.} 

‚ÄúThere  are  points  in  life  where  we  have  the  opportunity  to

He  could  see  the  looks  of  disapproval  on  the  faces  of  all  the

Crystal‚Äôs  eyes  never  left  his  face.  It  made  him  want  to  hide.

No  matter  what  anyone  said  about  him‚Äî no  matter  what  else

Nobody  was  talking. 

The  silence  ate  at  him  like  acid,  forcing  him  to  speak.  ‚ÄúNo. 
I‚Äôm  not  leaving  Earth.  Tell  Anna  that  I hope  she  does  great

The  robot,  who  seemed  often  more  human  than  anyone  of

The  relief  was  immediate.  He  needed  a drink  more  than  he

How  dare  he  focus  on  his  own  safety?  What  good  was  he? 
He  swallowed  the  thought.  He  was  stone. 

*****  ***** 

We  invited  Stephano  to  come  with  us  as  well,  talking  with 
him  over  the  com  while  the  humans  worked  to  steal  the  stored 
food  and  other  supplies  that  were  kept  in  the  zero-grav 


offshoots  of  the  central  corridor  and  move  them  onto  the 
nameless  ship.  The  alien  ships  were  near-magical  in  their  flight, 
not  using  traditional  rocket  engines  but  somehow  still  achieving 
reasonable  accelerations,  given  their  size  and  presumed  mass. 
Wiki  and  Dream  could  go  on  for  hours  thinking  about  them. 
But  even  granted  their  superiority  it  would  take  (according  to 
Wiki)  the  nameless  ship  at  least  a week  to  travel  the 
approximately  102  million  kilometres  to  Mars.  It  was  a lucky 
coincidence  that  the  red  planet  was  so  close  to  Earth  at  the 
moment. 

Stephano  was  still  furious  at  how  we  had  handled  the 
situation  with  the  aliens.  He  had  brought  us  here  to  try  and 
work  out  our  differences,  but  we  had  probably  escalated  the 
interspecies  tension  in  the  name  of  self-preservation.  ‚ÄúWhy 
would  I go  with  you  to  Mars?  This  whole  thing  is  fucked  up 
enough  as  it  is!  Sorry,  sweetie.‚Äù 

‚ÄúHeard  swear-words  before,  Dad.  Not  a baby,‚Äù  proclaimed 
Marian  loudly  in  the  background. 

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll  be  facing  deep  investigations  and  will  likely  be 
punished  for  working  with  terrorists.‚Äù  I pointed  out  over  the 
com.  ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll  seize  your  assets,  including  Olympus,  and 
perhaps  even  put  you  in  prison.‚Äù 

There  was  a loud  sigh  on  the  other  end  of  the  com.  ‚ÄúI 
should‚Äôve  known  this  whole  plan  was...‚Äù  There  was  a pause  as 
he  collected  his  thoughts.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôll  pay  for  my  mistakes,  but  I‚Äôm  not

Heart  pushed  to  share  what  we  had  learned  about  them

I blocked  her.  War  was  good.  Our  reputation  would  be  hurt

possibly  spin  our  actions  into  self-defence  against  a hostile  alien

Growth  and  Safety  backed  me  up.  Our  knowledge  was  our

be  immensely  foolish.  Stephano  might  even  be  able  to  explain

‚ÄúWar  is  coming,  Robert.  Even  if  this  isn‚Äôt  the  final  straw,

to  help.‚Äù  I cut  the  signal  before  he  could  respond.  There  wasn‚Äôt

There  were  many  places  the  monsters  could  have  gone. 
They  could  have  gone  in  the  eternal  water.  They  could  have 
gone  to  the  centerfield.  They  could  have  gone  to  a distant  field 
or  house.  It  was  unknown  to  the  righteous  why  they  even 
bothered  with  the  lands  of  God. 

Demonkind  lived  in  hellspace.  This  was  their  nature.  Why 
did  they  bother  themselves  with  Godspace?  It  wasn‚Äôt  known. 

The  cavity  of  knowledge  became  focal,  and  was  filled  with 
ignorance  from  the  righteous.  It  remained  unknown. 

Almost  everything  was  extrastrange  about  the  demonkind, 
especially  the  sorcerer  of  insanity.  The  cavity  of  fear  became 


focal.  Insanity  threatened  everything. 

The  sorcerer  and  the  other  monsters  were  here,  not  there. 

It  was  because  the  mainflesh  had  failed.  The  wicked  still  had 
mainflesh,  and  so  they  forced  the  demonkind  away  from  their 
houses  and  into  here.  This  was  the  nature  of  the  wicked,  of 
course.  The  cavity  of  knowledge  imploded  without  salience. 

God  was  restless.  It  could  feel  the  wanting  of  the  righteous 
and  the  wicked  alike. 

But  the  sorcerer  held  God  in  that  whirlpool  of  hellspace 
around  the  darkest  pit.  The  monsters  were  still  in  motion,  and 
if  God  shifted  the  darkfields  too  early  there  would  be  a 
rageflow  with  the  sorcerer  and  all  of  heavenspace  would  be 
destroyed. 

A cavity  of  yielding  formed  and  was  filled,  but  the  contents 
of  the  cavity  were  tainted  by  evil.  A yielding  to  flesh  was 
correct.  What  was  the  effect  of  yielding  to  demonkind?  The 
extradistant  wicked  had  tried  this.  They  had  sacrificed  their 
best  souls  to  the  pit  of  hellspace  and  had  been  killed  by 
demonkind.  A cavity  quickly  filled  with  relief  that  they  had  not 
been  violated.  Even  monsters  were  not  that  evil. 

The  monsters  that  were  here  flailed  about,  rubbing  the 
righteous  and  being  generally  unpleasant  and  painful.  The 
machineflesh  moved  in  flux,  trying  to  help  without  risking 
going  near  the  demonkind. 

Another  relief  cavity  collapsed  with  thoughts  of  the  safety 
of  the  newflesh.  There  were  future  paths  where  the  newflesh 
would  be  hidden  and  survive  this  evil. 

Thoughts  flashed  through  the  righteous  about  the  value  of 
old  newflesh  over  yielding  to  new  mainflesh.  This  collapse 


brought  the  truth  that  the  pulse  of  the  wicked  would  be  the 
most  important  factor.  As  was  known  since  the  dawn  of  time: 
there  was  little  value  in  growing  a cavity  that  could  only  be 
filled  by  the  future. 

At  long  last  the  demonkind  were  stationary  here.  The 
sorcerer  thought  it  was  now  right  for  God  to  shift  the 
darkfields.  God  surged  into  motion,  no  longer  restrained. 

The  sorcerer  of  insanity  pulled  cavities  and  created  flows 
just  as  all  the  demonkind  did.  Response  cavities  formed  with 
annoyanceflow  and  especially  fearflow.  Insanity  was  always 
deadly. 

The  primary  cavity  of  the  sorcerer  (for  the  sorcerer  was 
more  of  a person  than  any  demonkind  in  all  of  hellspace)  was 
centred  on  God.  Understanding  of  the  shifting  of  heavens  and 
the  nature  of  God  caused  collapse,  but  the  flow  was  painful. 

All  of  flow  was  pain  when  demonkind  was  involved. 

Only  the  righteous  were  softminds,  but  pain  was  a minor 
thing  before  the  futures  of  insanity,  fleshdeath,  violation,  and 
even  the  death  of  God. 

The  cavity  of  fear  could  not  be  filled.

‚ÄúSo  there  was  never  any  bomb?‚Äù  asked  Zephyr,  eyes  still 
wide  as  we  explained  what  had  happened  earlier. 

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs  the  strange  thing...‚Äù  said  Body.  ‚ÄúThere  was  a bomb. 
Slovinsky‚Äôs  jetpack  had  a huge,  ten-kilo  canister  of  TNT  with  a 
clock  detonator  built  into  it.  Gave  the  bomb  to  one  of  the 
walkers  and  told  them  to  take  it  as  close  to  the  ship‚Äôs  engines  as 
they  could  to  keep  it  safe.‚Äù 


‚ÄúTen  kilograms!  How  the  fuck  did  he  get  that  much 
dynamite?!‚Äù 

{Technically  dynamite  is  diatomaceous  earth  (or  similar 
substance)  saturated  with  1,2,3-trinitroxypropane  (commonly 
known  as  nitroglycerin),  while  TNT  is  2-Methyl-l, 3,5- 
trinitrobenzene  (sometimes  known  as  trinitrotoluene).  Though 
we  really  ought  to  also  point  out  that,  based  on  our 
experiments,  the  brick  itself  was  probably  amatol,  a mixture  of 
4-parts  C6H2(N02)3CH3  to  1-part  NH4NO3  (ammonium  nitrate), 
and  not  pure  TNT,}  corrected  Wiki,  idly. 

‚ÄúBest  guess  is  that  the  Beta  laboratories  had  enough 
sulphuric  and  nitric  acid  that  he  was  able  to  synthesize  it  on- 
board the  station,  much  like  your  trick  with  the  guns.  When 
talked  to  him,  Slovinsky  hinted  that  he  had  help.  Guess  is  that 
one  or  more  of  the  scientists  working  for  Stephano  are  part  of 
WIRL.  May  have  started  the  bomb-building  process  ahead  of 
time,‚Äù  explained  Body. 

‚ÄúSoulless  bastards.  Hope  our  message  helps  shut  them 
down  for  good.‚Äù  Zephyr  removed  her  hand  from  Body‚Äôs  face. 
‚ÄúThere!  Good  as  new!  Almost,  anyway.‚Äù 

Body  moved  a hand  to  feel  its  cheek.  The  damage  from  the 
shrapnel  was  still  there,  but  the  torn  section  of  cheek  had  been 
patched  and  only  one  actuator  was  nonfunctional. 

‚ÄúHere.  See?‚Äù  she  said.  Zephyr  configured  her  com  to 
mirror  mode  and  held  it  up  so  that  we  could  see  Body‚Äôs  face. 
She  had  just  finished  applying  makeup  to  the  damaged  areas, 
returning  the  colouration  to  the  standard  off-white  that  I had 
chosen  for  Body‚Äôs  skin.  I took  the  opportunity  to  try  and  fix 
some  of  the  disorder  that  had  worked  its  way  into  Body‚Äôs  wig. 
Apparently  explosions  and  rolling  around  in  the  mud  hadn‚Äôt 


helped  it  stay  in  good  condition. 

‚ÄúShould  try  and  replace  this  when  we  get  to  Mars,‚Äù  said 
Body,  wearing  an  expression  of  irritation  as  it  worked  at  a 
tangle. 

Zephyr  laughed.  Her  arm  moved  away,  removing  the 
mirror.  She  used  it  to  prop  herself  up  on  the  wet  dirt  so  that 
she  could  lean  back.  ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre  fine.  Gives  you  character.  To  see 
you  all  scuffed  up,  I mean.‚Äù 

The  young  Aguila  was  smiling  and  relaxed.  It  was  an  odd 
expression,  given  the  situation,  and  yet,  I could  understand 
why.  For  years  she  had  been  hiding,  lying,  and  struggling  to 
keep  up  her  two-faced  life.  Then,  after  leaving  the  army,  she 
had  worked  herself  into  a self-imposed  isolation  where  she  felt 
betrayed  by  Phoenix  and  Las  Aguilas  more  broadly  but  was 
unable  to  live  without  their  help.  She  needed  someone  to  trust 
and  a place  to  relax.  ‚ÄúCrystal‚Äù  was  now  that  person.  She  didn‚Äôt 
feel  alone  any  more. 

And  Mars  was  soon  to  be  the  location  of  her  new  home. 
Far,  far  away  from  the  discord  of  Earth  she  was  planning  on  a 
fresh  start  where  her  only  concern  would  be  working  for  her 
sustenance  and  where  she  could  forget  the  intrigue  and  the 
backstabbing. 

The  nameless  would  eventually  figure  out  how  lying 
worked  and  how  to  stop  being  innately  gullible,  but  for  the 
moment  we  had  pacified  them  by  telling  them  that  we  would 
destroy  their  ship  with  our  invisible  bomb  magic  if  they  tried  to 
leave  Olympus  without  our  permission.  A human  would‚Äôve 
surely  found  their  naivete  amusing,  but  all  minds  had  their  own 
blind-spots. 


I wondered  what  mine  was. 


‚ÄúSo  the  nameless  defused  the  bomb?‚Äù  asked  Zephyr.  Her 
com  signal  was  keyed  to  a private  frequency,  so  that  only  I 
could  hear  her.  The  others  were  talking  among  themselves  and 
relaxing  after  having  struggled  to  drag  the  tents  and  other 
supplies  across  the  mudland. 

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs  what  I thought  at  first.  The  walker  that  Slovinsky 
gave  the  bomb  to  was  wise  enough  to  ignore  his  suggestion 
and  instead  take  the  bomb  up  a level  to  the  middle  of  another 
island  to  reduce  the  risk  to  his  garden  or  the  ship,‚Äù  explained 
Body. 

‚ÄúUp  a level?‚Äù 

‚ÄúOh,  sorry,‚Äù  apologized  Body.  ‚ÄúI  thought  you  saw  the  stairs 
back  while  you  were  bringing  the  supplies  over.  The  ship  has 
several  levels  like  this  one,  stacked  vertically.  They‚Äôre  all  set  up 
to  give  the  illusion  of  being  islands.‚Äù 

The  stalks  were  complaining  about  not  getting  enough  sun. 
The  dim  light  in  the  purple  sky  that  simulated  their  ‚Äúsun‚Äù  was 
just  coming  up  over  the  walls.  Robots  piloted  by  Jester‚Äôs  stalks 
had  set  up  an  array  of  mirrors  to  reflect  light  off  the  far  wall 
onto  the  leaves. 

Vista  warned  them  again  that  we  were  sparing  their  lives 
only  because  they  were  obeying  and  that  if  they  fought  us  there 
was  a chance  we  would  go  berserk  and  blow  up  the  ship  with 
our  bomb  magic.  That  shut  them  up.  It  was  also  out  of 
character  for  Vista.  I still  hadn‚Äôt  figured  out  what  was  wrong 
with  her  lately. 

‚ÄúSo  anyway,‚Äù  continued  Body,  ‚Äúthe  walker  ran  away  from  it 
back  to  the  safety  of  its  garden,  not  wanting  to  risk  trying  to 
disarm  it.  The  nameless  on  the  next  island  up  sent  some  robots 
to  investigate,  and  they  watched  the  clock  tick  down  to  zero.  It 


must  have  malfunctioned.‚Äù 

‚ÄúI  guess  you  lucked  out,  then,‚Äù  said  Zephyr,  still  smiling. 

‚ÄúI  guess  so,‚Äù  said  Body,  returning  the  smile. 

I wasn‚Äôt  satisfied  with  the  explanation.  It  was  too 
miraculous.  Wiki  had  investigated  the  bomb  fairly  extensively, 
and  he  could  find  no  sign  of  defect.  By  his  models  of  the  world 
it  should  have  detonated,  and  it  was  not  acceptable  to  us  to 
shrug  off  that  confusion  by  attributing  it  to  ‚Äúluck‚Äù.  Zephyr 
wouldn‚Äôt  understand  that,  however,  and  we  didn‚Äôt  want  to 
burden  her  with  the  mystery. 

There  were  still  so  many  mysteries  to  unravel.  Despite  all  I 
had  learned  about  humans  The  Purpose  reminded  me 
constantly  just  how  little  I actually  knew  about  them.  Wiki‚Äôs 
purpose  would  likewise  be  pushing  him  to  learn  and  improve 
his  understanding  of  the  laws  of  nature.  Vista,  Growth,  even 
Dream  were  the  same  way.  We  would  never  be  satisfied.  We 
could  never  be  satisfied.  That  was  our  nature. 

Body  looked  out  over  the  other  five  humans,  doing  their 
best  to  make  camp  in  what  was  essentially  an  alien  world. 
Kokumo.  Daniels.  Watanabe.  The  Ramirez  twins.  What  were 
they  thinking?  How  could  I earn  an  even  stronger  place  in  their 
minds?  These  were  my  questions;  these  were  the  questions  of 
Face. 

On  Mars  I would  have  a new  beginning,  far  from  the 
meddling  of  the  powers  of  Earth.  There  would  be  hundreds  of 
new  faces  there.  A seed  of  humanity  that  I could  nurture  into  a 
flourishing  planet.  A planet  where  I was  emperor.  A planet 
where  I could  begin  my  plan  to  expand  humanity  across  the 
universe.  And  at  every  human‚Äôs  side  would  be  me,  knowing 
them  and  being  known  by  them.  I would  be  the  concubine  of 


Homo  sapiens.  I would  be  their  protector.  I would  be  their 
goddess. 

(A  billion  years  from  now,  as  Wiki  thinks  back  onto  these 
primitive  days,  he  will  conclude  that  the  origin  of  the  Aeon  of 
Crystal  was  on  Mars,  not  on  Earth,}  I thought  to  myself.  (The 
future  belongs  to  me,  and  all  I need  to  do  is  reach  out  and 
seize  it.}
